stem: The nurse is setting up a dry-suction chest drainage system. Place the setup steps in the correct order.

options.text: Connect the system to the wall suction unit.
Fill the water seal chamber to the specified level (usually the 2-cm mark).
Verify the presence of a 'suction-on' indicator (orange bellows or float).
Adjust the suction regulator on the unit to the prescribed setting (e.g., -20 cm H2O).
Connect the drainage system to the client's chest tube.

rationale.correct: System preparation ensures patient safety. (1) Water seal must be primed first to provide the protective seal. (2) Connecting to the client happens *after* the seal is ready. (3) Attaching to wall power. (4) Turning up the 'vaccum' pressure on the box. (5) Visual confirmation that suction is actually being applied (orange bellows).
rationale.incorrect: Connecting the client to the box before filling the water seal exposes the pleural space to atmospheric pressure.
clinicalPearls: In a dry-suction system, the amount of suction is determined by the dial on the drainage box, not the suction level set on the wall regulator.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the 'wall' suction must be high enough to make the box work, but the box 'dial' controls the actual pressure in the patient's chest.

reviewUnits.heading: Thoracic Drainage Systems Management
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor the water seal for tidaling and the drainage collection for volume/composition. All connections must be taped and secure.
reviewUnits.source: Nursing Care of the Thoracic Surgical Patient
